generation: Another week just flew by. I drove past the new house yesterday, and the front window was covered in boxes. We might get the keys at closing; I am so excited. If everything goes well this week, we are set for closing a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3:00 a.m. last night watching movies with Bethany. There's been a lot of movie-watching going on around here lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched "Thirteen," a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched "Gigli"—yes, it was just as bad as the media said it was, but we had to see for ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats, but now there are two great new shows I've been watching religiously for the past week. "Blow Out" presents the most flamboyant concept ever, surprisingly featuring zero visible gay people. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin wants to open a second location for his incredibly popular West Hollywood salon, this time in Beverly Hills. Normally, no one would care—certainly not me—but while flipping through the channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan, equally narcissistic and dull, looking at an empty space on Rodeo Drive, saying in a big public voice, "I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!" and I was hooked. Not since "Rocco" have I found such a moron to be so compelling to watch on TV.

What a week... My right shoulder has tendinitis, right under my shoulder blade. When I move my arm too much, especially while using a mouse on a computer, it’s incredibly painful. I can’t move it much now because I went on a spree updating my website and working on other online projects. I can barely muster the strength to draw anything. Lack of sleep adds to my discomfort. I'm not too happy at the moment, but I’ll get better. My mom’s surgery went okay. Her eyesight has recovered slightly—she can see fuzzy shapes and distinguish colors. Other than that, she’s still as blind as ever. Hopefully, she’ll fully regain her vision soon.

Kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest things can become an ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet total strangers can be, simply because they feel like being kind. Trust me, it wasn't like they were trying to get into my pants or anything. I had kid drool all over me and was wearing my 'wash-day' outfit. Also, I'm not super sure I'll ever be bathing again, so it's not like there was even an olfactory incentive there! I am doing two things right now: composing a post and watching the collected No Doubt videos, both while sitting at my desk in my room.

It's 11:14 PM MST, and here I am in my bedroom, fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. I don't mind doing it, but sometimes I wonder how often I end up fixing someone else's computer as a favor. I'm glad to be able to help and support people this way, but where is the line drawn before you're being taken advantage of? Over the last couple of weeks, I've been staying up late reading and such, so I was looking forward to going to bed early, until I realized it would be more prudent to return this computer to its owner. *laugh* No rest for the weary, right? So I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

Could you remind me what I wrote about before this? Or, perhaps, this is a continuation in the "Is this a date?" saga. So, after the awkward lunch, with my confidence shaken, I realized I forgot to tell you an important part of the story. Before Pat showed up for lunch, Dustin began talking about what a nice guy Pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. As I listened and nodded, I realized we were talking more about finding a girl for Dustin's best friend than about whatever you typically discuss over pink lemonade with a stranger. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror, and silently asked: Am I being set up with the other guy? Is this what's happening now?

I would like everyone to think before they act. In fact, I'd like each and every person in the world to consider their actions before getting out of bed in the morning and commit to thinking all day. If they're not prepared to do so, I'd very much prefer they hop back into bed and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm utterly tired of dealing with foolish people. No, I'm not claiming to be the smartest person in the world, but I'm not referring to matters that demand a lot of brainpower. Therefore, I believe it's fair to criticize those who are recklessly ignorant. Let's see if I can limit this particular rant to a few types of individuals, and we can save others for another day, sound good? Great.

Do you ever have one of those moments when you start reflecting on life? Like you're sitting in math class, bored out of your mind, and you wonder what exactly happens in your brain that helps you understand math. Then you realize that you exist, you're in math class, and you ask yourself why. You start to appreciate how amazing existence is. Suddenly, it hits you—this random train of thought is incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? I hate that. You know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who came up with that idea? Anyone can see that sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current Governor of Uttar Pradesh warned, as early as 1996, about the impending threat of the rise of a "Third Islamic State" in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the present Governor of Uttar Pradesh, predicted this serious threat in a series of articles published in The Hindustan Times back in 1996. Shourie raises a valid point when he asks, does knowing that it was Rajeswar, and not him, let alone Mr. Advani, who wrote those warnings make them ring true? Or do you conclude that because Rajeswar wrote them, he must be a hidden communalist and should not remain the Governor of Uttar Pradesh?

Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater I was knitting. I had only completed about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). But I had too many stitches by the time I got to the armholes, and the mohair was knotting itself together as I knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn't work well. The yarn broke frequently. Last night in class, we discussed that week’s assigned reading, "Getting Back Into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter addresses “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” In the first chapter, Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He suggests that centering culture around place creates a more grounded community. (This is a very rough summation, just a disclaimer in case my professor or any classmates read this post.) So far, this is the first book that has truly grabbed my attention.

This was a great weekend. I indulged in nature's bounty, and after a long time, I listened to a lot of Nevermore (something I should have started doing much earlier) and read extensively. I completed three books over the weekend: Bruce Sterling's "Heavy Weather," Larry Niven's "World of Ptavvs," and Octavia Butler's "Parable of the Sower." "Heavy Weather" was an engaging cyberpunk journey through a near-future USA, ravaged by global warming and general anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced, and very convincing, I must confess that I didn't leave with any particularly significant impressions about the story or the characters. Not that they aren't well constructed or vividly described—it’s a good book, but not a great one, I suppose.

Fall 1974: I was attempting, for what felt like the 13th time, to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then, nor am I now, a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies, and just as I was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that, my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door, and once more, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs—an uninvited practical joker.

You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always reside in me. Even if I never carried your child, even if I was never married to you, even if I never officially partnered with you... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling echoes through my heart. I will always be reminded of the few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of a beach evening... Or that kiss under the rain. Whenever I feel a dark glass piercing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me... And still remains. ... For her.

Yesterday, we had an outing with my colleagues from the bank to Guintubdan, La Carlota. It was the first visit for most of us. We embarked on a trek to the falls, which took about 30 minutes. We were all out of breath—whew!—but we made it. The water was icy cold, and you could feel your body numbing from the chill. We stayed for less than an hour before heading to a nearby waterfall, which was another 30-minute trek. The trip was worth it, as the falls were calming, and the entire scene was truly breathtaking. It felt as if we were becoming one with nature. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth. The cool air and water were enough to lull you to sleep.

Some people are eager to connect this dot: the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) was invited by the State Department to monitor the election. Observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. This marks the first time such a team will be present for a U.S. presidential election. Linking this to another dot: a group of congressional Democrats, including four from New York, has petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to deploy international observers to Florida for this year's presidential election. I humbly disagree. Based on the information available, it seems the OSCE is coming here to learn from the U.S. election process, not to oversee it, contradicting the original partisan and immature request for U.N. involvement.

The GOP is criticized for recruitment tactics as naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are set to be relocated after complaints that GOP activists registered new citizens as Republicans. By Gary Fineout and Alfonso Chardy. The citizenship ceremony in Jacksonville appeared to proceed as usual, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Just before the new citizens departed the June 29 event, an immigration official supervising the swearing-in encouraged them to visit a voter registration table—a common sight at naturalization ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: the volunteers handing out forms were Republicans, and the party affiliation box had been pre-checked to make all new voters members of the GOP. This aroused suspicion in Linda Cross, who attended to watch her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

Hello, so I saw "Troy" tonight with my family, and I was not impressed. I'm too tired to delve into specifics, but I do think it had potential. However, too much energy seemed to be spent on the set, which was truly magnificent, and not enough on establishing a cohesive tone or theme. It retold the story, but it wasn't particularly gripping, and I don't feel like I gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, I thought the score was poor, essentially a knock-off of "Gladiator." "Gladiator" used background music with a moaning woman effectively because it supported and complemented a genuinely captivating narrative.

Urllink, let's give a warm welcome to the newest atom/RDF/RSS reader on the scene, Urllink PulpFiction 1.0 from Urllink Freshly Squeezed Software. This app seems packed with native app features. It's important to note that it isn't free, which seems to be a 'hot topic' on the internet again. You can try it free for 15 days and then either switch back to another app or pay $25 if you decide you like it. A standout feature is that each post functions as an individual entity, allowing you to move, store, label, and even delete it. I can see how this feature would appeal to those who track news meticulously. It also supports the import and export of OPML, just as one would expect.
