It puts the ball in the net or it gets the hose again. Absolutely amazing—I have nothing negative to say about this game as it has exceeded my expectations and will likely exceed yours too. The movement is fluid, it's free from bugs and crashes, and there's a wealth of story and content to engage with. You have options for each day, such as multiple practices, events (sponsorships), and even games. This review is based solely on playing MyCareer, and so far, it's a 10/10. The face scan worked really well for me (although the first attempt gave me a forehead that didn't look quite right). Remember, using the MyNBA2K17 app allows you to face scan for free and earn daily VC. #sellout

Magic fans, beware... Wizards seems reluctant to create a truly satisfying digital game. At its heart, Magic: The Gathering is a social game meant to be enjoyed with friends (or frenemies), filled with laughter, banter, and dramatic game-winning moves. Wizards of the Coast appears to have forgotten this. If you decide to play with friends, you can't earn gold—and gold is crucial. It's so vital that they've set a daily cap, which is understandable since gold unlocks everything in the game. But brace yourself for a long and monotonous 1v1 grind against the computer or random opponents, whom you can't even communicate with. If you opt to play for free, it will take you roughly 4 hours a day for over a month, by yourself, to unlock the cards.

Being the third installment in the trilogy, I'll address the drawbacks first. I really dislike prequels as they move backward in the storyline instead of forward (a common issue with prequels). Although they offer more in terms of story, the combat in this installment feels sloppy and lacks the sharpness that Arkham City achieved. As of writing this review (26/10/2013), there is a game-breaking bug that prevents a side mission from being completed (though the main story remains unaffected). Some gadgets are assigned to an inconveniently placed hotkey, requiring a stretch across the keyboard. While this may seem minor, it can potentially disrupt your combo during combat.

They improved Shadow Warrior (2013) significantly. The boss fights are excellent, and the weapons feel satisfying—perhaps not quite on par with those in Doom 2016, but still solid. Enemies aren't too resilient, provided you're adept at managing elemental and upgrade aspects. The upgrade system is well-balanced, and once you get the hang of it, it's not too cumbersome. The elemental features and limited ammo naturally encourage you to use a variety of weapons. There are many cool, unique weapons (a key point when comparing to Borderlands' formula of 'RNG' weapons) that remain viable for most of the game. The music is fantastic, especially the main theme and Stan Bush's contributions.

So many things were done wrong. I don't even know how to start this review. This all refers to MyCareer. My player is an outside scorer, a point guard, 1.71m tall, with maxed stats and all necessary perks. Okay, now tell me, why does shooting skill depend on a person's height? Why can someone who is 1.74m not become as good at shooting as someone who is 1.71m? I'm 1.87m in real life, made my first player with this height, and noticed I can't reach a higher skill than 89. Why? That's pure discrimination! And why doesn't the game tell me that before I create a character or even when I reach the skill limit after weeks of playing?!

I think this Assassin's Creed game nailed the mechanics across the board, from ship battles and sailing to hunting (fish) and parkour. I felt much more attached to this character as well. The story starts off quite rough but improves significantly as you progress (I think this is true for every AC game, personally). Edward was a particularly interesting character, as were all the side characters. I felt like all the collectibles actually meant something in this AC game, which I never got from any of the previous ones. Perhaps it’s because they seemed to have a bigger purpose in the game. They definitely weren't required, but they were fun to collect, and the rewards were very balanced.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it's not entirely terrible. The gunplay is decent, as long as you can afford to buy gun parts. My main complaint is that the game operates on a pay-to-win model. If I could overlook that, the game would be enjoyable since the hardsuit is fun to use and HRV is an excellent concept. I would choose this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you're okay with this model, then by all means, enjoy. However, if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, it's best to pass on this one; it's not our cup of tea.

While not perfect, this game has been thoroughly enjoyable. The save system and the possibility of sudden death can lead to some frustration. I'm on my first playthrough and lost my main character around hour 10 of an approximately 20-hour experience. I would have appreciated a save to reload at that point. I've since picked up a third-party mod/save tool to avoid catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticule is somewhat small, and the zoom is underpowered. Despite these issues, it's been a blast. I'm not usually a fan of zombie games, but the combination of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat 'em up elements is fantastic. I've been playing it as often as I can—just one more mission, just one more supply run—or I'm running away and want to secure a safe spot before shutting the game down.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every other wargame, like European Escalation and ALB, I must say this one fits in perfectly. The number of units is impressive; I'm not sure exactly how many there are, but there's a ton! The graphics are stunning, the sounds are excellent, and the gameplay overall is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is quite entertaining as well—I'm not kidding. However, if anyone thinks this game is 'easy' or you're new to the strategy genre, it might take some time to master. Don't get discouraged; you will lose a lot of units. Just make sure you plan ahead and always have anti-air and anti-tank defenses.

I was initially biased against this game before I played it and wasn't even sure about buying it. I don’t know; the whole portal gun and portals concept seemed odd to me, even though I like science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting in this game are phenomenal—simply amazing. It's not cheesy (okay, sometimes it is), and each character has their own unique sense of humor and distinct personality. And the level design? It's just fantastic. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I'm planning to, if I can find the time. I would never have played it if I hadn't played the sequel.

Alright, let's start with the pros (+) and cons (-), followed by my thoughts on this game. 

+ Some of the best characters
+ Good story
+ Lots of content
+ Customizable character (you can choose to be male or female)
+ You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest)

- Poor graphics (though I don't think graphics really matter)
- Weird and awkward love scenes
- Invisible walls
- There's one mission that, in my opinion, was boring, but everyone has different tastes

+- This isn't really bad or good, but for those who care, your protagonist can't talk.

Now for my thoughts. I love this game. It is probably one of the best RPGs or games in general I have ever played. If you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgic journey for thirty-somethings who remember (especially in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallett just to catch the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others have returned and are instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is present. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is perfect and very reminiscent of Generation One. Beyond that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are extremely well done. Transforming mid-fight often becomes necessary and is seamlessly woven into combos, making it quite distinct from High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, although some enemies (e.g. Seekers) require switching to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played it for a little while, but it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There's a bug where it says there's an update to the terms of service, and whenever you click 'accept,' it just pops up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. That isn't too bad, but why do I need to link my Steam and GFACE accounts? They say it's for DLC, but why is that even necessary? It's also not reversible, so now a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. As for the game itself, it's just okay. It's easily recognizable as a COD clone, but somehow, they made the gunplay worse. How is that even possible?

4K resolution at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear—what's not to love? Check it out: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nygsb617tmo. It's an excellent port and a great entry point for newcomers to the series. Keep in mind, though, there's a lot of (skip-able) dialogue. As usual, it's recommended to use a gamepad; however, I personally had no issues with a keyboard/mouse setup, both of which are completely rebindable. The price is reasonable, and I wouldn't have been unhappy with the purchase. More than half of the DLC is included for free, providing ample content to enjoy. I recommend this game to all fans of JRPGs/anime/visual novels, as long as you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers. No commentary playlist: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=plslfvijaupszez9af395mvnk63xnhsj1_

I experienced no performance issues even at release, and after all the patches, it plays exceptionally well. In my opinion, this is truly a great and entertaining game, although the format can be somewhat annoying (as the free-roam city area repopulates with new enemies every time you progress in the story). I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments (where you can play as Batman along with one other character), and I greatly appreciated the ability to use the controller for most parts of the game and switch to the mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments. Driving your Batmobile around the free-roam city—especially when chasing the APC commanders—becomes quite enjoyable once you master using the brakes to skid around corners. Once you get the hang of it, driving around the city is truly enjoyable!

Damn fine AAA FPS shooter—that's the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays great—excellent FPS mechanics, a nice story, cool characters, flawless voice acting, and a badass soundtrack. Not for the faint-hearted though—some of those cutscenes were quite cruel and vivid. But when a game is so great overall, it's easier to spot the flaws, and here they are as I saw them: - no SLI support—seriously? I had to put the game aside until I upgraded my card, as it ran poorly on my old dual GPU GTX 590. Make sure you have a fairly decent single GPU card. - Ridiculously small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language; I am Dutch. Therefore, please overlook any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories: 

- Graphics: The game is designed in a comic-like style. The graphics are very sleek, with no unnecessary details and nice color schemes. It totally works for this game. The graphics can be set to 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M card and 8GB of memory, and it runs smoothly on Windows 8.1. 

- Controls: The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse, as well as with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I've put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. However, don't buy this game thinking it's like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter game. It's in a class of its own and should be treated as such. I can't tell you how many times I've heard new players complain about getting killed really fast. Oh, heaven forbid you get shot in the face and actually die. It's not like that doesn't happen in real life or anything. Edit: Okay, so I've been playing this game for a while now. I've invested all sorts of money into it. It's one of the best multiplayer games around and a great choice when you're not in the mood for CS:GO.

I'm two hours in, and I'm already hooked on this game. It's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, the music is surprisingly high-quality and fitting, and the story and world have captured my interest. The puzzles are fun as well. However, the standout feature of this game is the comedy. If you've played any RPG since they first emerged, you'll appreciate the various jokes, parodies, and references. Even if you've never played an RPG before, you'll still enjoy the humor. If you've played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you absolutely need to try this game. Without revealing too much... I actually had to stop playing after two hours to give my cheeks a break from laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far.

I'm really sorry; I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded right up my alley, but the execution did nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this game to be completely unintuitive, and even after looking up how to progress, I still just didn't find the gameplay itself fun. It also completely lacks a pause button, or if it does have one, I never found it. Considering that a lot of sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is more cut scene than game, and I end up sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.

This game... Phew, where do I even begin? It was absolutely beautiful; from the story to the graphics, I was completely hooked. The story wasn't just any story; it genuinely felt like I was the character, trying to figure out what came next. The gameplay was excellent, and I learned a lot about myself through this game (mainly my fear of heights, which I never had an issue with until the ice caverns). My gut churned the entire time, but I pressed on for Uncle Fred! If you guys made a DLC or a sequel, I would be the first to buy it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in making this; you created an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization towards a specific goal or "victory." In previous games, you followed Earth's timeline, progressing through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age. However, in this game, you're set in the future on a mission to colonize a new planet. What I enjoy about this game is that 2K adopted a fresh approach by introducing new mechanics such as the Affinity System and Orbital Layer. However, I found that these new mechanics could make the game somewhat overwhelming at times. One area of improvement for the game could be incorporating more diverse artwork, particularly in the environments encountered during interactions with other leaders.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival experience! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more "realistic" zombie games. It's designed very much like a survival horror game, as you must conserve your ammo, heal your wounds when you bleed, take pills when you're infected, etc. I also find the zombies to feel very natural and well-animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly, and you can usually make friends/talk with people in the chat or over voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's a shame I can't fully recommend or enjoy this game. From the short time I've played it, I know I'd be addicted if it weren't for the following two game breakers: 

1. No Australian servers - One red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. I even played through the offline training mode, and it was stuttering and lagging as well (how does that even happen?). Coupled with poor ping, it just ruins the game.

2. Everything artifacts like crazy - menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game. I've never experienced this before with this card, and I thought it might not like my overclock. I set my GPU back to stock, and sure enough, it didn't make a difference.

Very late last night, I finished this. The story isn't very deep or interesting, but what makes it stand out is the storytelling. The atmosphere is rich, and the many collectibles do a great job of fleshing it out. I did learn a lot about the world of Batman, so it was a bit disappointing that there were so few bosses in the game. Oh well, there are enough future games to rectify that. The combat offers the right amount of challenge, though it's more on the easy side. Leveling up Batman wasn't very satisfying; it's the gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign that add nice new gameplay mechanics. Gaining access to previously unreachable places provides a nice sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game; it is a veritable experience and one of the best of my life. Think Telltale's 'The Walking Dead' is sad? Well, it's no match for 'To the Moon'! Never before have I been so depressed yet fulfilled by something purely fictional. This masterpiece represents the pinnacle of storytelling, in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a gorgeously charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky, and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I did not care one bit. Plus, the humor in the game is great and does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story... And the Doctor Who references are endless.

Bastion is a brilliant game with an engaging storyline. Set in the aftermath of a calamity, you embark on rebuilding the bastion. The game offers plenty of choices, including deciding what to construct for strategic advantages, selecting weapons and power-ups, and choosing drinks for bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic, with vibrant visuals that prove the apocalypse doesn't have to be dull. Best of all, the game features narration that responds to your actions. For instance, if you pick up a weapon and then swap it for another, the narration will comment on your choice of the new weapon.

I originally bought this game during its early development stage, back when the only currency was spacebux and there was no 'tech tree'. During this time, the game was very enjoyable. All the guns were equally overpowered, so there were no issues with imbalance; everyone could defeat anyone at any time. Additionally, the game provided unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would expect that in a game boasting 'bajillions of guns,' they would offer more than just 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before requiring you to pay for more. At one point, I had accumulated about 3 pages of guns and was brainstorming new ideas for more because, personally, that's where I found the fun.

This game turned out to be a delightful surprise. Often, rave reviews can be misleading, but in this case, they perfectly capture the fun of this unique little game. It blends the elements of a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA with style. I enjoyed characters in this game that I typically wouldn't in other MOBA games. I had anticipated the same disinterest with others but decided to try a melee tank anyway. I was pleasantly surprised by the experience and ended up experimenting with more characters as they became available through gameplay. The art style and interface are uniquely charming. Consequently, I now use one of the characters as my avatar and have created a wallpaper for the game from a card set.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself in the game for hours at a time. It's been a while since a game has had that effect on me. The music sets the mood perfectly, the sound effects are spot-on, and the controls are flawless. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized it extremely well. I had my doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets at a time! The only way to lose in this game is by failing to retreat. If the combat looks overwhelming, just get out of there, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced several changes to the series, particularly affecting its protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series might be upset by the changes to their beloved character, these changes are indeed for the better, as demonstrated by the new game developed by Ninja Theory. "DMC" serves as the perfect entry point for newcomers to the series. It showcases the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante, and it chronicles his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout the game, a clear narrative arc is woven for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to watch. The story follows Dante as he is introduced to the corrupt world he had willfully chosen to ignore.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, filled with incredible detail, and it's a bundle of happiness, bad puns, annoying dogs, and secrets. The game is serious when it needs to be but isn't a stranger to funny moments. The character design is exceptional, featuring a variety of characters with diverse personalities and secrets. It stands out from other RPGs because you don't have to kill anyone, which is a unique concept in the genre. Drawing lots of inspiration from EarthBound, one of the best RPGs I've seen, you can tell it's going to be great. It easily boasts the best soundtrack I've heard in ages.

I am recommending this solely because it's free and might be a more enjoyable experience for others. However, for me, the "game" did nothing. Half the story relies on shock value. I was neither shocked nor emotionally moved in any way. Perhaps I'm desensitized, or maybe it was too simple to evoke a reaction from me. The other half of the game attempts to portray (literally) a person in mental decline, dealing with obsession, hallucination, depression, and other issues. In theory, it's a cool idea, but the "game" took me just 10 minutes to complete, even after reading and absorbing every detail possible.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then lets you explore it. It's an excellent way to challenge your mind while still being fun. Although the game isn't heavy on story, it gave rise to one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play and complete this game when I'm feeling bored, and I love revisiting what gave birth to a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is fairly simple to describe. You use portals to your advantage, along with buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: one you press and one that requires a cube to keep it pressed.

If you can overlook the bugs (I personally encountered only two: one minor and the other quite annoying), I can definitely recommend this space exploration game. Edit: both bugs have been resolved, and one fix increased my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120. Since most reviews focus on specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~€200), Radeon RX480 (~€200), Z170 Pro-Gaming (~€150), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~€70). Overall, this setup cost around €650, placing it within the medium price range. However, this rig is relatively new. I consistently get 60+ FPS on high settings with VSync enabled. I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments claiming they have an overkill setup and only achieve 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? Yes, it's been quite a while since an RTS game of such quality has come along. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes very close to my favorite RTS game, combining it with a grand strategy mode similar to Risk. This combination truly hits the spot for me. I try not to be overly biased, but the ability to transform into a dragon and support, attack, and command troops simultaneously is quite appealing. Honestly, I do enjoy complex RTS games these days, like Civilization V and others, but those tend to cram many complex mechanics, charts, and resources into one intricate game mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title and the music is pleasant, but together they create some truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script ranges from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, and it does this while cleverly subverting traditional RPG tropes. And all of this is achieved without even delving into the world, characters, story, or gameplay—subjects I could write entire pages about. But instead, I'll just say this: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you enjoy video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and the end of your life, play this game.

I've only had this game for a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, which is evident in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a fairly steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I'm still trying to master; however, this depth of strategy offers you a myriad of ways to achieve goals and capitalize on certain situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself absorbed in every session I play, regardless of how the playthrough is going.

Warframe is an enjoyable game during the first few hours of play. However, after those initial hours, you may find that the game primarily offers repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. A major highlight of the game is that the developers are committed and frequently update it, often introducing significant content changes, new warframes, and various tweaks/features. It's a good game for casual play, though I doubt it will hold your attention beyond a few months unless you particularly enjoy grinding. The positive aspect is that the game is free, so I recommend giving it a try. If you're looking for something quick and engaging, it's worth checking out.

This game is incredibly boring. I bought it thinking it was the PC version of 'Katamari Damacy,' a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Unfortunately, it falls far short of that. In this game, you move around absorbing increasingly larger objects to grow, allowing you to absorb even bigger things. However, the gameplay isn't as smooth as it should be, the levels lack creativity, and what's present is more like a surreal horror show. I don't mean an entertaining horror show but one that leaves you feeling depressed and questioning if life is all it should be. Every 'living' creature in the game, from small pets to humans, makes me wonder if the creators had an interest in taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was quite intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!" Well, it really wasn't. The game starts you off by asking you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat—there is no independent or third-party option. A little disappointed but still optimistic, I continued to see what I could do. I'll give the game credit; the character customization, although limited, is pretty fun to play around with. It's the only time you have the option to campaign with or without your head, literally.

The story in Fallout 3 was superior. Settlements interfere with the narrative to such an extent that you'll find managing them frustrating instead of focusing on the story. Some keys are hard-coded and can’t be reassigned. The game is rife with bugs. At one point, my Pip-Boy disappeared permanently, and I had to research console commands to retrieve it. Power armor is practically handed to you from the start, and power cores are plentiful in trader shops. This significantly diminishes the value of power armor compared to previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, and the game overall is average—though it doesn’t crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3, making it more stable by comparison. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Better than New Vegas? No. This title was tremendously overhyped considering how disappointing it truly is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): - 8.6 hours to reach the end - 10 collectibles found out of 25 - zero achievements out of 15 What I liked: - visuals up to the last level (ice caves) - the story isn't great, but the ending (after the closing credits) somewhat justified the time spent playing What I disliked: - visuals in the last level are uninteresting - gameplay in the last level becomes much harder, turning it into a frustrating experience of repeating tasks until you succeed - achievements are too difficult. Only less than 2.1% of players have achieved 13 out of the 15 achievements!

Pros: + Great graphics

Cons: - Bugs (especially in the environment, where you may get stuck or your shots hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy) - The game holds your hand too much - Dumb AI - Enemies always seem to know your location once you're spotted - Frustratingly godlike accuracy from enemies, similar to the first Ghost Warrior - Poor checkpoint system and saves - Unengaging story that I couldn't care less about. I would not recommend it unless it's 90% off; even then, playing the game feels like an exceedingly tedious task, played just to finish it and move on to the next game in my library. Given the time I wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (which was equally boring and left me feeling relieved when I finished it), I probably won't play it to the end.

Review from 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game; the servers are offline, so you can't play. No compres este juego; los servidores están offline. No puedes jugar. While I was able to play it, I enjoyed it. As the Steve Miller Band song goes: "go on take the money and run uh uh uhhh! go on take the money and run go on take the money and run go on take the money and run" https://youtu.be/-wcfugcollu?t=54. English - 73 minutes playing the game. OMFG, just an hour into this game and it's awesome! Some guns are overpowered, and the matchmaking is sometimes unfair. But hey, BF3 had worse matchmaking. The newbie players and high-level players weren't real humans; you'd shoot them in the face and nothing happens!

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? :D This puzzle-platforming game features a little character with a fez who goes around collecting small pieces to form a cube and navigates through a large, branching map. The game is amusing, and completing it is quite fun. ^_^ It can become somewhat frustrating if you aim to collect all the cubes and achievements, though. To gather all the cubes, you'll need to crack codes that must be deciphered. These can take a few seconds or might frustrate you into consulting a guide (*raises hand* I gave up. -_-). The guide, "A Complete Guide to Fez!!!

It's easy for me to understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn’t for me. For one thing, I have a Vive and I'm much more interested in playing room-scale games with the controllers. Additionally, while the game's universe is initially awe-inspiring in its scale, I found that this same scale hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the amount of time required to engage in anything interesting at the beginning were both too steep for my liking. Perhaps if I were more patient and had more time for gaming, this would be compelling to me. However, I lack both and there are plenty of other VR games I’d rather spend my time on.

Without a doubt, this is my favorite first-person shooter of all time. It's not for those who favor run-and-gun tactics. The recoil and ballistics are remarkably realistic: a single hit to the chest, neck, or head from a rifle-caliber weapon almost always results in death unless it just grazes you. Bullets drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are necessary to stay on target. There isn't an unlimited ammunition pool; if you consistently reload halfway through a magazine, you'll end up with a collection of half-full mags. You can't run indefinitely—if you sprint for a while, your aim will suffer as you catch your breath. Steady your aim by resting your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a window sill. Accuracy diminishes when standing.

Let me start by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out; I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some people claim to have had with that game. I loved that game, though it was unforgiving in the early stages, it was rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM 2, I love it. The game plays pretty well for me on medium settings, and I am running a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game set itself to high, and it was running a bit sluggishly, but not to the point of being unplayable. When I lowered it to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm just lucky regarding having issues with games or what, but it seems most of the negative reviews come from some really entitled people.

+ RPG leveling + wide variety of ship types + physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles + easy-to-learn resource management + dark humor - grind intensive (if underutilizing the civvy station types) - sub-par AI teammates - low variety of equipment types - low variety of leveling skills (no branching)

Listen, this game is incredibly fun. Despite the negatives mentioned, there is still variety and strategy to explore. It starts quickly and continues to build momentum. Even though there’s a limited variety of equipment, it always feels like there’s another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to extend the game’s longevity is through mods. "Fight for Universe" is undoubtedly the highlight, but "Big Fight for Beef" is also excellent.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Over five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future following this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Unlike in previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalization campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run concurrently with the WEF’s more upscale event in Davos.

As the deadline approaches for the Fiat-GM agreement, Fiat and General Motors (GM) have until midnight on 1 February to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover. This deadline is significant because it signifies when Fiat will have the right to sell its car division to GM, an option established as part of an alliance formed in 2000. GM, whose European operations are currently losing money, is now reluctant to acquire the unprofitable Fiat unit. News of stalled negotiations caused Fiat shares to drop by 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% increase on Monday fueled by hopes of a payoff. The U.S. company is reportedly offering around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to exit the agreement. GM claims the contract was invalidated when Fiat decided to sell its finance arm and reduced GM's stake through a capital-raising initiative. The 2000 alliance stemmed from a competitive pursuit between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal Criticizes Iraq War: Billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has said. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made these comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance during his Christmas Midnight Mass. The Cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. Both he and the Archbishop of Canterbury have spoken out against the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticized the fact that "billions" have been spent on war instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." The Cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make poverty history.

British Stars Denied Major Oscars

British hopes of securing major Oscars were dashed as UK stars failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" did not take home the director or screenplay awards, and there was no prize for star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet lost the Best Actress award to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to win Best Supporting Actor awards. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film award for her gritty drama "Wasp." Arnold, who hosted children's television shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. "Wasp" tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, surpassing films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, a screenwriter and producer known for her work on the 1970s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film that featured Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, the film grossed over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide, setting a record for independent films at the time. Hill also collaborated with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, Hill started her career as a production assistant, eventually rising through the ranks to become an assistant director and second-unit director before her partnership with Carpenter. She was considered a pioneering woman in the film industry, taking on roles in the 70s that were predominantly held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression as fast web access encourages more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and have personal websites, according to a report by UK think tank Demos. The report stated that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is rapidly growing. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's internet habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged onto the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse online. More significantly, the report argues, broadband is encouraging people to take a more active role online.

Yukos Returns to U.S. Courts: Russian oil and gas company Yukos is due in a U.S. court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is being dismantled by Russian authorities to pay a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the U.S., hoping to leverage international business law to halt the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. Despite their efforts, the unit was sold for $9.4 billion to state oil firm Rosneft, but only after the state auction was disrupted. Yukos' lawyers now argue that the auction violated U.S. bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have pledged to pursue any company that acquires its assets, using all available legal means.

Voters are flocking to the blog awards site as voting is underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs—online spaces where people publish their thoughts—of the year. Nominations were announced on Sunday, but traffic to the official site was so heavy that it temporarily shut down due to too many visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs had a remarkable year, with a leading U.S. dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and notes that more than 12,000 are added daily. According to the U.S. research think tank Pew Internet & American Life, a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, but less than 40% of the total are updated at least once every two months.

Chinese Dam Firm 'Defies Beijing': The China Three Gorges Project Corp is refusing to comply with a government order to cease construction of one of its massive dams, according to the Chinese state press. Despite the order, the builder of the Three Gorges Dam continues work on the Xiluodu Dam, the Beijing News reports. The Xiluodu Dam is among 30 major projects halted due to insufficient environmental checks. Instead of halting, the company might opt to pay a fine, according to the Beijing News. The firm has also disregarded orders to stop construction at two other projects: the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. So far, only 22 of the 30 construction projects identified by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) for not completing mandatory environmental impact assessments have complied with the shutdown order.

Manchester United closed Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points with a hard-fought 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney connected with Gary Neville's cross at the near post, and his low shot deflected off Richard Dunne to give United the lead. Seven minutes later, the unfortunate Dunne volleyed the ball over David James and into his own net. Steve McManaman missed City's best opportunity, shooting wide from three yards out in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United seemed unlikely to secure the win they needed to keep their title hopes alive. Their play was more labored than patient, and they only managed to create one chance—a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons,' says the new health minister, who believes there are lessons to be learned from England in addressing waiting lists. Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role following Jane Hutt's dismissal, acknowledged "big challenges" but emphasized that the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats insisted that Dr. Gibbons needed to change his policy approach. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, claiming that waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi in the upper Afan Valley before becoming an AM for Aberavon, stated that NHS staff desired a period of consolidation following "tremendous change and reform." One of the major problems Ms. Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half years as the assembly's first health minister was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson Praises Man Utd’s Resolve: Manchester United's Alex Ferguson lauded his team's gritty performance in the 1-0 victory at Aston Villa. "That was our toughest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic match of football, end-to-end with lots of excellent passing," said the Old Trafford manager. "We showed a lot of character and guts, and we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to visit, and Villa may have some players back by then." Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy came on and brought a bit of composure to the midfield, which we needed and which no other player can provide.

A documentary offering a candid look at the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be shown at this year's Berlin Film Festival. "A Different Story" will screen in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from February 10-20. It features the singer discussing both his career and personal life, from his days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on February 16. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be present. The 93-minute film includes Michael's reflections on his early days in Wham!, his later career, his legal battles with record label Sony, and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads have entered the US singles chart as digital music downloads are being included in the main US singles chart for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from digital music sales, which were previously confined to a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two on Billboard's pop chart and tops its digital chart. Download sales are scheduled to be incorporated into the UK singles chart later this year. In the US, digital sales already contribute to compiling Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. These sales will now be combined with physical single sales and airplay data to form the new Hot 100 chart. The chart's second new component, the Pop 100, also merges airplay, digital, and physical sales but limits its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws hit spammer hard as the net's self-declared "spam king" seeks bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, the man behind OptInRealBig.com and billions of junk mail messages, stated that lawsuits had forced the company into Chapter 11. OptInRealBig was fighting several legal battles, most notably against Microsoft, which is pushing for millions of dollars in damages. The company said filing for Chapter 11 would help it attempt to resolve its legal issues while still continuing operations. Listed as the third biggest spammer in the world by junk mail watchdog Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for sending mail messages that violated anti-spam laws. The lawsuit was brought by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who alleged that Mr. Richter and his accomplices sent billions of spam messages through 514 compromised net addresses in 35 countries.

Arnesen Denies Rift with Santini

Tottenham's sporting director, Frank Arnesen, has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation suggesting that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "The sole reason for his resignation was his own personal problems. He has spoken to me recently and stated that this matter is entirely personal." Arnesen mentioned that he was unable to shed light on the issues that led Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added, "Jacques has never detailed exactly what these issues were. But I trust him on that; we have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past the Scots as they maintained their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by halftime. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed the victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Meanwhile, Scotland will aim to give their coach, Matt Williams, a first Six Nations victory when Italy comes to Edinburgh, but they again struggled to convert pressure into points.

Britain's economic future will be central to Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has stated. He spoke after cabinet members held their final meeting at No. 10 before the expected election announcement. Brown asserted that voters would recognize Labour's role in bringing stability and growth and that this would continue. Meanwhile, the Tories outlined their plans to address "yob culture," and the Lib Dems provided more details about their proposals to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to exploit people's fears during the election. In an open letter, he called on them not to make the election a contest about who can best scare voters regarding terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to Run at AAA's in Sheffield

Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls competing in this weekend's AAA Championships. U.S.-based athletes Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish participants selected so far for the Europeans who will not compete in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title at the British trials.

In-form athlete James McIlroy aims to secure his spot on the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has shown impressive performance on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and seems well-assured of a place in Madrid.

Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European Championships. Carroll is currently ranked number three in the world for the 3000m, with Cragg holding the top position.

Robinson Aims for Dual Code Success: England rugby union captain Jason Robinson is aiming for dual code success against Australia this Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, will lead England in their match against Australia at Twickenham at 14:30 GMT. Later, at 18:15 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team will face Australia in the final of the Tri-Nations Tournament. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for the league," said Robinson. England has the opportunity to secure their third autumn international victory after consecutive wins over Canada and South Africa, and to avenge June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of losses against Australia with a victory at Elland Road.

A warning has been issued regarding a scam website that claims to collect money on behalf of tsunami victims, urging internet users to be cautious. The site appears convincing as it uses an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, the DEC has no association with the fraudulent site and has reported it to the police. This site is merely the latest in a series of scams attempting to exploit the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. The website link is included in a spam email currently circulating. The email's subject line is "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal," and its content features poor grammar and bad spelling, typical of many other phishing attempts.

Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to significantly enhance nationwide coverage over the next decade. The Ministry of Communications announced that bids are welcome from local, Arab, and international companies. The successful bidder will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry expressed its ambition to raise Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to approximately 25% within 10 years." Additionally, it seeks to develop a "highly visible and transformative telecommunications sector." Details regarding the bidding and tender process will be available on the ministry's website on February 9. The ministry is also planning an investor roadshow in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to internet security as both older individuals and women increasingly take charge of protecting home computers from malicious online attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to defend PCs against viruses, spam, and spyware rose by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. The study, conducted for the net security firm Preventon, indicates that security messages are reaching a diverse group of internet users. It is estimated that 40% of those purchasing home internet security programs are retired, with an average yearly increase of 13.2% over the past three years. Notably, more retired women (53%) are buying security software compared to retired men. The research highlights the evolving stereotypes and demographics of web users and reflects the rising awareness of the greater risks posed by high-speed broadband internet connections.

Podcasts signify the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, which is a considerable amount of space to fill. Increasingly, iPod owners are filling that space with audio content produced by an eclectic mix of creators. This phenomenon is known as "podcasting," with its most ardent advocate being former MTV host and VJ (Video Jockey) Adam Curry. Although the term "podcasting" derives from the Apple iPod, you do not need an iPod to create or listen to a podcast. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show that podcasters can create, typically from the comfort of their own homes. All that's required is a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. Podcasters then upload their shows to the internet, allowing others to download and listen to them, all for free.

Andrea Levy, an Orange Prize winner, has seen her novel, "Small Island," win the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award. She is now the favorite to win the overall prize, having bested Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." Geraldine McCaughrean has claimed the Children's Fiction Award for the third time with "Not the End of the World." All category winners will compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which comes with a £25,000 prize. A judging panel, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will convene on January 25th to decide the overall winner, with the announcement occurring later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has made Levy's London-based novel the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on the sale. Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm that purchased its main asset. Yukos has stated it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' US lawyers will try to have Baikal's assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a US court order last week that blocked the sale. Baikal's background and motives for purchasing the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal—which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction—has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts secured a 2-1 victory over Livingston in their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie, scoring two goals within the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller netted the opener in the very first minute, heading the ball over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister himself added the second goal, connecting with Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, putting the game out of reach for the visitors. Although Craig Easton scored a controversial goal for Livingston after an hour, Hearts maintained their lead. The opening goal followed a foul by Gus Bahoken on Miller, 35 yards from goal. McAllister delivered a free kick into the Livingston box, and Miller outjumped the static visiting defense to loop his header over Meldrum from 10 yards out. By the 10-minute mark, the home side had doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right and crossed to the back post, where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service, allowing customers who need substantial computing power to rent it by the hour. Through the Sun Grid, users are charged $1 (53p) per hour for processing and storage capacity on Sun-maintained systems. This concept, known as grid computing, is gaining traction in a company that views computing capacity as an essential commodity, comparable to hardware and software. Sun has compared grid computing to the evolution of electricity, suggesting it could mature similarly to utilities like electricity and water, stated Sun's Chief Operating Officer, Jonathan Schwartz. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson Issues Warning to Bigots: Scotland's Justice Minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to hit them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are among a series of measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue. However, the minister emphasized that curbing sectarian abuse associated with Old Firm matches is a key objective. Ms. Jamieson spoke ahead of the third round Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the Executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the issue.

UK Debut for Kevin Spacey Movie: Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of their new film, "Beyond the Sea," in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, which is inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife—real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with her British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds vs. Saracens (Fri) Headingley - Friday, 25 February, 20:00 GMT. The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley received the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future, as the fixed line phone in your home may soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia reveals that more and more people are using their mobile phones for every call they make or receive. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, the US, and South Korea now solely use a mobile phone. It was found that people keep their fixed line phones because call charges are lower, but the majority of those questioned believe that the future is undeniably mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research indicated that mobiles and fixed phones serve different purposes. Home phones are used for longer calls, while conversations on mobiles tend to be shorter, typically occurring between mobiles and with friends. In the UK, 69% of those surveyed said they opted for their fixed phone because it remains cheaper to use than a mobile.

Melzer Stuns Agassi: Second seed Andre Agassi suffered a comprehensive defeat by Jurgen Melzer in the quarter-finals of the SAP Open. Agassi was often baffled by the Austrian's drop shots in San Jose, losing 6-3, 6-1. Defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick rallied to beat Sweden's Thomas Enqvist 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. Meanwhile, unseeded Cyril Saulnier defeated fourth seed Vincent Spadea 6-2, 6-4, and Tommy Haas overcame eighth seed Max Mirnyi 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. Melzer has now beaten Agassi in two of their three meetings. "I had a good game plan and I executed it perfectly," he said. "It's always tough to come out and play against Andre. I didn't want him to play his game. He makes you run all over the court like a dog.

MPs Tout Lords Replacement Plan: A group of MPs has attempted to increase pressure on Tony Blair concerning reforms to the House of Lords by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, with 70% of the members being elected. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group believes it can gain support for removing the last 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers, citing the likelihood of failure due to opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms. There have been suggestions that Labour's manifesto will include proposals for changing at least the powers of the Lords.

Disappointed Scott in Solid Start

Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the Jose M Cagigal Memorial meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equaled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64 seconds but ran 0.04 seconds slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A U.S. woman is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date. The unnamed woman from Georgia claims that a chip inside the cartridge signals the printer to refill the ink even when it is not necessary. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the U.S. who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use chip technology to detect low ink levels and advise users to make a change. However, the suit alleges that the chips also disable the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty.

Virgin Radio Offers 3G Broadcast UK broadcaster Virgin Radio has announced it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobile devices. In partnership with the technology firm Sydus, the radio station will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website to access the service. James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, stated, "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations, Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland added, "This application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music on Isle of Wight Bill

Roxy Music will perform at June's Isle of Wight Music Festival, alongside artists such as Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as the headliner for the three-day event, taking place from June 10-12. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take the stage on Saturday night of the festival. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," followed by others like "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy.

Captains Lining Up for Aid Match: Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on March 5th. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also part of the Northern team. Sir Clive Woodward will coach the Northern team against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fundraising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," Woodward said. This match will offer Woodward a chance to evaluate some options before revealing his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he added.

The comedy "Sideways" dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, and Alexander Payne, along with writing partner Jim Taylor, won Best Director and Best Screenplay. Acting awards were also given to stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. "Sideways" is expected to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, where it has five nominations. The Spirit Awards, now in their 20th year, are presented to films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who won Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay Award went to Joshua Marston for "Maria Full of Grace.

Prince Crowned 'Top Music Earner': Prince earned more than any other pop star in 2004, surpassing artists such as Madonna and Elton John in US magazine Rolling Stone's annual list. The singer accumulated $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concerts, album sales, and publishing, thanks to his Musicology tour and album. He kept Madonna in second place, with her earning $54.9 million (£29.5 million) from her global Re-Invention Tour. Veterans Simon and Garfunkel were in 10th place, with their comeback tour contributing to earnings of $24.9 million (£13.4 million) last year. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine reported. The singer's 2004 tour garnered $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

Tories have outlined policing plans where local communities would be asked to go to the polls to elect their own area police commissioner, under proposals unveiled by the Conservatives. Party leader Michael Howard stated that the new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities. He clarified that the new office would not override the position of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats expressed concern that this plan could allow extreme groups to influence policing, while Labour criticized the "extravagant" Tory promises on policing. In response to the plans, Jan Berry, chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, which represents rank-and-file officers, stressed the importance of maintaining operational independence. She remarked, "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every time an election approaches. These plans could result in those with extreme political views dictating what actually happens on the ground," she warned.

At a glance: Tory Health Checks

The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: 

- Individuals from outside the EU coming to live and work in Britain. 
- If they plan to stay for six months or more and hail from countries with high rates of TB, they would need a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. 
- All people from outside the European Union wishing to stay a year or more will be required to undergo a full medical examination. 
- Tuberculosis, Hepatitis B, and HIV are the conditions of focus. 
- A positive TB test would automatically result in visa application rejections.
